Russian Navy Fears Submarine Crew Is Dead The Russian navy said that all 118 members of the crew of the wrecked nuclear submarine Kursk are likely dead, or will be before British and Norwegian rescue teams can make another effort to open a rear hatch.

Clinton to Visit a New Nigeria On his second trip to Africa, starting next weekend, President Clinton will visit Nigeria, a country he overflew last time when it was ruled by the military and which has since undergone a convulsive transformation as it restores democracy.

Immigration Key in Italy's Vote The issue of illegal immigration is shaping up as a political bludgeon in Italy and is defining the battle between the ruling center-left coalition and its center-right opposition.

Colombia to Look Into Killings The Colombian government, in a test of its commitment to improving its human rights record, has promised a full-scale investigation into the killings by army troops of six elementary school children.

Clash Over Document Release Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright and George Tenet, director of central intelligence, are at odds over the extent to which the United States should release documentation of its involvement with Latin American regimes in decades past.
NATIONAL

Candidates Plan Ad Blitzes As Drive to Election Begins The presidential contenders plan next week to open the biggest television advertising blitzes of their campaigns, Gov. George W. Bush will emphasize education and Vice President Al Gore will trumpet himself as a champion of working families.
Mr. Bush traveled to New Mexico to announce a proposal to repair schools on Indian reservations.
Mr. Gore assailed Mr. Bush as a man who embraces the interests of corporations at the expense of the middle class.
California Test Scores Rise Spanish-speaking students in the state of California, which ended bilingual education two years ago, are improving in reading and other subjects at often striking rates.

Ford Considered Other Tires An internal Ford Motor Company document obtained by lawyers suing the automaker and Bridgestone/Firestone Inc. shows that the company considered using higher-pressure tires on its Ford Explorer but decided against them because they increased the risk that the Explorer would tip over.
Tighter Rules on Privacy The Clinton administration has decided to beef up protections for the privacy of medical records. But officials said the new rules would not give patients full control.
NEW YORK/REGION

Mayor Names Head of Jails As New Police Commissioner Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani named the head of New York City's jail system, Correction Commissioner Bernard B. Kerik as the city's next police commissioner, turning to a former undercover narcotics detective to command the nation's largest police department. Mr. Kerik, 44, will replace Howard Safir, Mr. Giuliani's confidant and friend of 25 years who announced his resignation after four and a half years in the job. At the Department of Correction, Mr. Kerik brought about substantial declines in violence in the jails
